column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Khan (Indonesia): Allow me to begin by\r
#Text=commending the President's work on convening today's\r
#Text=debate on the issue of sexual violence in conflict.
#Text=This\r
#Text=timely debate highlights the urgent need to address the\r
#Text=various forms of violence perpetrated against women\r
#Text=and girls.
#Text=Despite all the achievements and progress\r
#Text=that have been made in promoting the protection and\r
#Text=rights of women, such violence persists all over the\r
#Text=world.
#Text=Indonesia also wishes to thank the Secretary-\r
#Text=General for his report on sexual violence in conflict\r
#Text=(S/2013/l49), which is a valuable starting point for our\r
#Text=deliberations today on improving ways to eliminate\r
#Text=and prevent violence against women, particularly in\r
#Text=conflict situations.
#Text=At the outset, Indonesia associates itself with the\r
#Text=statement delivered by the representative of Viet Nam\r
#Text=on behalf of the member countries of the Association of\r
#Text=Southeast Asian Nations.
#Text=Indonesia notes with deep concern the use of\r
#Text=sexual violence as a tactic of war and one that worsens\r
#Text=its consequences, as highlighted in the Secretary-\r
#Text=General's report.
#Text=Against that backdrop, Indonesia\r
#Text=condemns all forms of violence against women and\r
#Text=girls in armed conflicts, particularly sexual violence,\r
#Text=which, as the report states, predominantly affects\r
#Text=women and girls but can also affect men and boys.
#Text=We wish to reaffirm our support for resolution 1325\r
#Text=(2000), the first to specifically address the impact of\r
#Text=war on women and women's contributions to conflict\r
#Text=resolution and sustainable peace.
#Text=The follow-up Security\r
#Text=Council resolutions on women, peace and security also\r
#Text=constitute a milestone for protection and empowerment\r
#Text=measures for women in the special situation of conflict.
#Text=Indonesia commends the adoption of the agreed\r
#Text=conclusions of the fifty-seventh session of the\r
#Text=Commission on the Status of Women (CSW), last month,\r
#Text=as a manifestation of the intergovernmental efforts\r
#Text=that have been made by countries under the United\r
#Text=Nations framework.
#Text=The agreement reached on the\r
#Text=agreed conclusions is a step forward in strengthening\r
#Text=countries' commitment to tackling violence against\r
#Text=women and girls.
#Text=The CSW conclusions send a clear and strong\r
#Text=message: violence against women and girls committed\r
#Text=in armed conflict and post-conflict situations is strongly\r
#Text=condemned; sexual and gender-based violence, which\r
#Text=affects victims, families, communities and societies,\r
#Text=is recognized; and effective accountability and redress\r
#Text=measures, as well remedies, are required.
#Text=At the national level, Indonesia's national action\r
#Text=plan on human rights serves as a strong platform for our\r
#Text=commitment to eliminate and prevent violence against\r
#Text=women.
#Text=The process of drafting a presidential decree is\r
#Text=ongoing, as a legal basis to formulate a national action\r
#Text=plan on the implementation of resolution 1325 (2000).
#Text=When completed, the action plan, among things, will\r
#Text=cover all phases ofthe peace process - from prevention\r
#Text=to ending conflict to recovery from social conflict.
#Text=Indonesia wishes to highlight some of the main\r
#Text=challenges in our efforts to eliminate and further\r
#Text=\r
#Text=prevent violence against women, including sexual\r
#Text=violence: first, insufficient gender-sensitive policies;\r
#Text=secondly, inadequate implementation of legal and\r
#Text=policy frameworks; thirdly, inadequate data collection,\r
#Text=analysis and research; fourthly, the lack of financial\r
#Text=and human resources and insufficient allocation of\r
#Text=such resources; and, fifthly, the lack of comprehensive,\r
#Text=consistent, sustained, transparent and adequately\r
#Text=monitored and evaluated efforts.
#Text=Those gaps have yet to be bridged by States as the\r
#Text=bearers of the primary responsibility in addressing the\r
#Text=issue ofviolence against women and its impact, in order\r
#Text=to translate commitments into practical approaches and\r
#Text=actions on the ground, to fashion more compassionate\r
#Text=responses for victims, to pursue more aggressive\r
#Text=prosecutions of perpetrators and to create more secure\r
#Text=communities and environments.
#Text=With its multifold economic, social and cultural\r
#Text=consequences, sexual violence in conflict hampers not\r
#Text=only women and men victims, but also their families\r
#Text=and communities.
#Text=Therefore, Indonesia supports the\r
#Text=six-point priority agenda established by the former\r
#Text=and current Special Representatives of the Secretary-\r
#Text=General on Sexual Violence in Conflict.
#Text=To conclude, Indonesia would like to reiterate the\r
#Text=importance of the international community, including\r
#Text=the United Nations, as the key stakeholder, joining\r
#Text=hands and providing support for States to address the\r
#Text=remaining gaps and tackle the gravity of the situation.
#Text=Indonesia also urges all parties to conflict to comply\r
#Text=with international humanitarian and human rights law.
